project: Smart Home Security System — AegisGuard Pro

requirements.text: The system shall detect unauthorized entry through [doors AND windows] within 2 ± 0.5 seconds of the breach event.
requirements.rationale: Homeowners require immediate detection of intrusion attempts to ensure family safety and enable rapid response.

comments.text: Core requirement — verified against ISO 62443 security standards.
comments.author: Sarah Chen

comments.text: Requirement approved after security architecture review.
comments.author: David Park

requirements.text: The system shall notify the homeowner of security events via [mobile push notification AND SMS] within 5 ± 1 seconds of event detection.
requirements.rationale: Homeowners need real-time awareness of security events whether at home or away.

comments.text: 200ms threshold validated with hardware team. Sensor polling rate supports this.
comments.author: Mike Torres

comments.text: Performance requirement approved for CDR baseline.
comments.author: David Park

requirements.text: The system shall provide continuous video surveillance of the property perimeter with a minimum resolution of 1920 × 1080 pixels at 30 ± 2 frames per second.
requirements.rationale: Property owners require clear visual evidence for insurance claims and law enforcement cooperation.

requirements.text: The system shall operate continuously for a minimum of 72 ± 4 hours on battery backup during power outages.
requirements.rationale: Power outages are a common vulnerability exploited during break-ins; continuous operation is essential.

comments.text: Need to verify 128-bit AES is sufficient or if 256-bit is required by compliance.
comments.author: Sarah Chen

comments.text: Updated to AES-256 per compliance review. Please re-review.
comments.author: Mike Torres

requirements.text: The system shall enable the homeowner to arm and disarm the security system remotely via a mobile application within 3 ± 1 seconds.
requirements.rationale: Homeowners frequently need to control the system when away from the property.

requirements.text: The system shall comply with UL 2900-1 cybersecurity requirements for network-connected products.
requirements.rationale: UL certification is required for retail distribution and insurance company partnerships.

comments.text: Battery life target may be aggressive. Requesting hardware team input.
comments.author: David Park

requirements.text: The intrusion detection subsystem shall process signals from each door and window sensor and generate an intrusion alert within 1.5 ± 0.3 seconds of sensor activation.
requirements.rationale: Allocates the 2-second stakeholder detection window between sensor processing (1.5s) and alert generation (0.5s).

requirements.text: The notification service shall deliver push notifications to the AegisGuard mobile application within 3 ± 0.5 seconds of alert generation by the central controller.
requirements.rationale: The 3-second allocation plus 1.5-second detection meets the 5-second stakeholder notification window.

requirements.text: The notification service shall deliver SMS messages to the registered phone number within 4 ± 1 seconds of alert generation.
requirements.rationale: SMS serves as fallback when mobile data is unavailable; slightly longer latency is acceptable.

requirements.text: The video surveillance subsystem shall encode and transmit H.265 video streams at 1920 × 1080 pixels and 30 ± 2 frames per second with a maximum bitrate of 4 ± 0.5 Mbps per camera.
requirements.rationale: H.265 encoding reduces bandwidth by 50% vs H.264 while maintaining required resolution.

requirements.text: The central controller shall maintain a local video buffer storing a minimum of 48 ± 2 hours of recorded footage from each camera.
requirements.rationale: Local storage ensures footage availability even during network outages.

requirements.text: The battery management subsystem shall provide uninterrupted power to the central controller, sensor hub, and cellular modem for a minimum of 72 ± 4 hours when mains power is unavailable.
requirements.rationale: Direct allocation of 72-hour stakeholder requirement; video recording excluded during battery operation to conserve power.

requirements.text: The mobile application shall authenticate the user via biometric verification and transmit the arm/disarm command to the central controller within 2 ± 0.5 seconds of user confirmation.
requirements.rationale: 2-second app response plus 1-second network latency meets the 3-second stakeholder requirement.

requirements.text: The central controller shall encrypt each communication channel using AES-256-GCM with unique session keys rotated every 3600 ± 60 seconds.
requirements.rationale: AES-256-GCM meets UL 2900-1 encryption requirements and provides authenticated encryption.

requirements.text: The system shall perform firmware integrity verification using SHA-256 hash comparison at each boot cycle and reject firmware images that fail verification.
requirements.rationale: Prevents execution of tampered or malicious firmware; required by UL 2900-1 Section 7.

requirements.text: The central controller shall detect sensor communication loss and generate a tamper alert within 30 ± 5 seconds of the last successful heartbeat from each sensor.
requirements.rationale: Prevents attackers from silently disabling sensors by jamming or destroying them.

requirements.text: The door/window sensor module shall transmit a state-change signal to the sensor hub using 915 MHz ISM band within 200 ± 20 milliseconds of reed switch activation.
requirements.rationale: 200ms sensor transmission plus hub processing must fit within the 1.5-second system detection window.

requirements.text: The sensor hub shall aggregate signals from up to 64 sensors and forward validated intrusion events to the central controller via the internal bus within 500 ± 50 milliseconds.
requirements.rationale: 500ms hub processing allows 200ms sensor tx + 800ms controller processing within the 1.5s window.

requirements.text: The notification gateway shall maintain persistent connections to [Apple APNS AND Google FCM] services and retry failed delivery attempts a maximum of 3 times with 500 ± 100 millisecond intervals.
requirements.rationale: Persistent connections eliminate handshake latency; retries handle transient cloud service failures.

requirements.text: The IP camera module shall perform automatic white balance and exposure adjustment within 2 ± 0.5 seconds when ambient lighting conditions change by more than 50%.
requirements.rationale: Rapid lighting adaptation ensures usable footage during dawn/dusk transitions and when lights are switched.

requirements.text: The battery management controller shall monitor cell voltage, current, and temperature at 1 ± 0.1 second intervals and initiate protective shutdown when cell temperature exceeds 60 ± 2 °C.
requirements.rationale: Lithium battery thermal runaway prevention is critical for residential safety.

requirements.text: The reed switch sensor component shall detect a magnetic field change of 10 ± 1 Gauss at a maximum air gap of 25 ± 2 mm.
requirements.rationale: 25mm gap accommodates standard residential door/window frame tolerances.

requirements.text: The 915 MHz radio transceiver shall achieve a minimum receiver sensitivity of -110 ± 2 dBm at a data rate of 50 kbps.
requirements.rationale: Sensitivity specification ensures reliable reception through 2 interior walls at 30m range.

requirements.text: The lithium iron phosphate battery pack shall provide a rated capacity of 100 ± 5 Ah at a nominal voltage of 12.8 V with a cycle life exceeding 2000 charge cycles to 80% capacity.
requirements.rationale: 100Ah at 12.8V = 1280Wh; system draws 15W average = 85 hours, exceeding the 72-hour requirement.

requirements.text: The system should be user-friendly and easy to install with reasonable effort.
requirements.rationale: Ease of use drives customer satisfaction.

requirements.text: When a motion event is detected, it shall be processed quickly and the user should be notified promptly via the app if necessary.
requirements.rationale: Motion events need rapid processing.

requirements.text: The system shall use REST API and MQTT protocol to communicate between components, including but not limited to sensors, controllers, and cloud services.
requirements.rationale: Standard protocols reduce integration complexity.

requirements.text: The system shall be capable of supporting additional sensors and shall have the ability to integrate with third-party devices as needed.
requirements.rationale: Extensibility is important for product roadmap.

requirements.text: The cloud storage module shall upload encrypted video clips to the remote server and the data should be backed up regularly.
requirements.rationale: Cloud backup provides off-site redundancy.

risks.title: RF Interference Causes Sensor Communication Failure
risks.description: The 915 MHz ISM band is shared with other consumer devices (baby monitors, garage door openers, LoRa devices). High RF interference in dense residential areas could cause missed sensor signals, leading to undetected intrusions. Field testing in apartment complexes has shown interference levels 15dB above suburban baseline.
risks.notes: Investigating frequency hopping spread spectrum (FHSS) as mitigation. Prototype testing scheduled for Sprint 14. May need to add secondary 2.4 GHz backup channel.

risks.title: Cloud Notification Service Outage
risks.description: Dependency on Apple APNS and Google FCM means push notifications fail during cloud service outages. Historical data shows APNS has experienced 3 outages exceeding 30 minutes in the past 12 months. SMS fallback partially mitigates this but has its own carrier-dependent reliability issues.
risks.notes: Implemented dual-path notification (push + SMS). Also added local siren activation as tertiary alert mechanism independent of cloud services. Residual risk accepted by product owner.

risks.title: Battery Thermal Runaway in Extreme Heat
risks.description: LiFePO4 battery pack installed in non-climate-controlled garage or attic locations could experience thermal stress during summer months. While LiFePO4 is inherently safer than Li-ion, sustained ambient temperatures above 45°C combined with charging could push cell temperatures toward the 60°C shutdown threshold, causing nuisance shutdowns.
risks.notes: Evaluating passive cooling solutions. Installation guide will recommend climate-controlled locations. Considering adding active fan cooling as optional accessory.

risks.title: Firmware Update Vulnerability Window
risks.description: During over-the-air firmware updates, the system enters a 30-90 second window where the security monitoring loop is paused. An attacker with knowledge of the update schedule could exploit this window. Currently, updates are pushed globally at a predictable time (2:00 AM local).
risks.notes: Proposed solution: A/B partition scheme where update is applied to inactive partition while active partition continues monitoring. Seamless switchover on next boot. Requires additional flash storage — see DEC-0005.

risks.title: Supply Chain Delay for Custom Sensor Hub ASIC
risks.description: The custom sensor aggregation ASIC (AegisHub-1) has a single-source supplier with 16-week lead time. Any fabrication issue could delay product launch by 4-6 months. Current geopolitical tensions have increased semiconductor supply chain volatility.
risks.notes: Evaluating FPGA-based fallback design that uses off-the-shelf components. Would increase BOM cost by $12 per unit but eliminates single-source risk. Decision pending — see DEC-0006.

risks.title: False Alarm Rate Exceeds Customer Tolerance
risks.description: Early beta testing shows 2.3 false alarms per week per household, primarily from pet motion, HVAC drafts on door sensors, and spider webs on cameras. Industry benchmark for acceptable false alarm rate is less than 0.5 per week. High false alarm rates lead to alarm fatigue, system disarming, and negative reviews.
risks.notes: Implementing ML-based anomaly classification using edge inference on the central controller. Training dataset of 50,000 labeled events collected from beta program. Target: reduce false alarms to < 0.3/week while maintaining 99.7% true detection rate.

risks.title: UL 2900-1 Certification Delay
risks.description: UL 2900-1 certification process typically takes 8-12 weeks. If penetration testing reveals vulnerabilities requiring code changes, the certification cycle restarts. Two competitors have recently failed initial certification, suggesting increased scrutiny from UL.
risks.notes: Pre-certification security audit scheduled with independent firm (CyberSec Partners) for March. Early identification of issues should reduce risk of UL failures. Budget allocated for 2 certification cycles.

risks.title: Camera Privacy Regulation Non-Compliance
risks.description: Emerging privacy regulations in California (CPRA), EU (GDPR), and Illinois (BIPA) impose strict requirements on residential video surveillance data. Requirements for on-device processing, data retention limits, and consent mechanisms may require architectural changes if not addressed during design phase.
risks.notes: Legal review completed. Edge processing architecture (DEC-0003) naturally supports privacy-by-design. Adding configurable retention policies and privacy zone masking. GDPR Data Protection Impact Assessment scheduled for Q2.

risks.title: Installation Complexity Drives Up Support Costs
risks.description: Beta program reveals average self-installation time of 3.5 hours vs target of 1.5 hours. Primary issues: Wi-Fi range to sensor hub, sensor calibration, and mobile app pairing. 40% of beta users required phone support, averaging 25 minutes per call. At scale, this would cost $18 per unit in support.
risks.notes: Developing AR-guided installation feature in mobile app. Redesigning sensor pairing to use NFC tap instead of BLE scanning. Creating video tutorial series. Target: reduce average install time to under 2 hours and support calls to under 15%.

risks.title: Local Storage SSD Failure Causes Footage Loss
risks.description: The central controller uses a single M.2 SSD for local video storage. Consumer-grade SSDs have a 0.5-1% annual failure rate. Loss of the SSD means loss of all locally buffered footage. For units deployed in high-write environments, wear leveling may be exhausted within 3 years.
risks.notes: Resolved by implementing dual storage strategy: industrial-grade SSD with SMART monitoring for local buffer, plus automatic cloud sync of event clips. SSD health alerts added to maintenance notifications. DEC-0004 documents the storage architecture decision.

decisions.title: Wireless Protocol Selection for Sensor Network
decisions.decision: The sensor network shall use a proprietary protocol on the 915 MHz ISM band with frequency hopping spread spectrum (FHSS) rather than Zigbee, Z-Wave, or Wi-Fi for sensor-to-hub communication.
decisions.rationale: 915 MHz provides superior wall penetration compared to 2.4 GHz alternatives. FHSS mitigates the shared-band interference risk (RSK-0001). Proprietary protocol allows optimized packet structure for minimal latency (sub-200ms target). Z-Wave licensing fees add $2.50/sensor. Zigbee mesh introduces unpredictable latency. Wi-Fi power consumption is 10× higher, unacceptable for battery-powered sensors.
decisions.alternatives: Zigbee 3.0 (rejected: latency), Z-Wave Long Range (rejected: licensing cost), Wi-Fi HaLow 802.11ah (rejected: power consumption), Bluetooth LE (rejected: range insufficient for large properties)

decisions.title: Dual-Path Notification Architecture
decisions.decision: The system shall implement a dual-path notification architecture using both cloud push notifications (primary) and cellular SMS (secondary fallback), with automatic failover when push delivery is not confirmed within 3 seconds.
decisions.rationale: Cloud push notification alone has a 99.5% reliability rate, insufficient for a safety-critical system. Adding SMS as fallback brings effective reliability to 99.95%. The dual-path approach addresses RSK-0002 (cloud service outage). Cost impact is $0.01 per SMS; projected average of 2 SMS fallbacks per user per month = $0.24/year/user.
decisions.alternatives: Push notification only (rejected: insufficient reliability), SMS only (rejected: high cost at $0.01/message for all events), dedicated cellular voice call (rejected: excessive cost and user annoyance), satellite communication (rejected: cost prohibitive for consumer product)

decisions.title: Edge Processing for Video Analytics
decisions.decision: Video analytics (motion detection, person classification, object tracking) shall be performed on the central controller using an edge AI accelerator rather than streaming to cloud for processing.
decisions.rationale: Edge processing reduces cloud bandwidth costs by 85% (only event clips uploaded vs continuous streams). Eliminates privacy concerns about continuous video transmission (addresses RSK-0008). Reduces notification latency by 1-2 seconds. Operates during internet outages. Selected Google Coral Edge TPU providing 4 TOPS at 2W power envelope.
decisions.alternatives: Cloud-based video analytics (rejected: latency, bandwidth cost, privacy), hybrid cloud/edge (deferred: complexity for v1.0), no AI analytics (rejected: false alarm rate would be unacceptable per RSK-0006)

decisions.title: Dual Storage Strategy for Video Retention
decisions.decision: The system shall implement a tiered storage architecture: industrial-grade M.2 SSD for 48-hour local rolling buffer, plus automatic encrypted upload of event-triggered clips to cloud storage with 30-day retention.
decisions.rationale: Local-only storage risks total loss on SSD failure (RSK-0010). Cloud-only requires continuous upload bandwidth. The hybrid approach provides immediate local playback, cloud redundancy for event clips, and graceful degradation during internet outages. Industrial SSD (Samsung PM9A3) rated for 1 DWPD provides 5-year life at continuous recording workload.
decisions.alternatives: Local SSD only (rejected: single point of failure), cloud only (rejected: bandwidth cost and internet dependency), RAID-1 dual SSD (rejected: cost and physical space constraints), SD card storage (rejected: write endurance insufficient)

decisions.title: A/B Partition Firmware Update Architecture
decisions.decision: The central controller shall use an A/B partition scheme with dual boot partitions, allowing firmware updates to be applied to the inactive partition while the active partition continues security monitoring, with atomic switchover on validated reboot.
decisions.rationale: Eliminates the 30-90 second vulnerability window during firmware updates (RSK-0004). Provides automatic rollback if new firmware fails health check. Requires additional 512 MB flash storage ($1.20 BOM increase) but eliminates the security exposure entirely. Industry best practice per NIST SP 800-193.
decisions.alternatives: Single partition with monitoring pause (rejected: security vulnerability RSK-0004), differential patching on running system (rejected: complexity and corruption risk), user-scheduled updates with explicit monitoring pause (rejected: user burden, still has vulnerability window)

decisions.title: FPGA Fallback for Sensor Hub Processing
decisions.decision: An FPGA-based sensor hub design using Lattice iCE40 shall be developed as a parallel backup to the custom ASIC (AegisHub-1), to be activated if the ASIC supply chain experiences delays exceeding 4 weeks beyond the committed schedule.
decisions.rationale: Custom ASIC has a single-source supplier with 16-week lead time (RSK-0005). FPGA design uses commodity parts available from multiple distributors with 2-week lead time. BOM cost increase of $12/unit is acceptable as a schedule risk mitigation. FPGA prototype can also serve as the development platform while ASIC samples are in fabrication.
decisions.alternatives: Accept schedule risk with ASIC only (rejected: 4-6 month delay would miss holiday launch window), switch entirely to FPGA (rejected: long-term BOM cost $12 higher at scale), software-only implementation on main CPU (rejected: insufficient real-time performance for 64-sensor aggregation)

decisions.title: LiFePO4 Battery Chemistry Selection
decisions.decision: The backup battery pack shall use Lithium Iron Phosphate (LiFePO4) chemistry rather than standard Lithium-ion (NMC/NCA) or Lead-Acid.
decisions.rationale: LiFePO4 provides inherent thermal stability (thermal runaway onset >270°C vs ~150°C for NMC), addressing RSK-0003 battery safety concerns. Cycle life of 2000+ cycles vs 500 for lead-acid reduces total cost of ownership. Energy density is sufficient for the 72-hour requirement (100Ah at 12.8V = 1280Wh vs 1080Wh needed). Flat discharge curve maintains consistent voltage throughout discharge. UL 9540A listing simplifies residential installation certification.
decisions.alternatives: NMC Lithium-ion (rejected: thermal safety concerns for unattended residential use), Lead-Acid AGM (rejected: 3× heavier, 4× fewer cycles, hydrogen off-gassing risk), Lithium Titanate (rejected: excessive cost at $800/kWh vs $250/kWh for LiFePO4)

decisions.title: NFC-Based Sensor Pairing Replacement
decisions.decision: Sensor pairing shall transition from BLE scanning to NFC tap-to-pair, where the user taps each sensor against the hub to register it, replacing the current multi-step BLE pairing flow.
decisions.rationale: Beta testing reveals BLE pairing accounts for 35% of installation support calls (RSK-0009). NFC tap requires no user configuration, no PIN entry, and completes in under 2 seconds. NFC hardware adds $0.40/sensor and $1.20 to the hub. Projected support cost savings of $6.50/unit over first year far exceed BOM increase.
decisions.alternatives: Improve BLE pairing UX with better instructions (rejected: fundamental UX complexity remains), QR code scanning (rejected: requires line-of-sight and good lighting), pre-paired sensors shipped with assigned hub (rejected: eliminates sensor replacement flexibility)

glossary.def: System of Interest — the AegisGuard Pro Smart Home Security System
Interface Control Document — specifies communication protocols between subsystems
Verification and Validation — processes to confirm requirements are met
Concept of Operations — describes how the system is intended to be used
Apple Push Notification Service — Apple's cloud service for delivering push notifications to iOS devices
Firebase Cloud Messaging — Google's cloud service for delivering push notifications to Android devices
Frequency Hopping Spread Spectrum — RF technique that rapidly switches carrier frequencies to reduce interference
Industrial, Scientific, and Medical radio band — unlicensed frequency bands (including 915 MHz)
Advanced Encryption Standard 256-bit with Galois/Counter Mode — authenticated encryption algorithm
Application-Specific Integrated Circuit — custom-designed silicon chip optimized for a specific function
Field-Programmable Gate Array — reconfigurable integrated circuit used for prototyping and low-volume production
Lithium Iron Phosphate — battery chemistry known for thermal stability and long cycle life
Nickel Manganese Cobalt — lithium-ion battery chemistry with high energy density but lower thermal stability
Tensor Processing Unit — specialized AI accelerator for machine learning inference at the edge
Drive Writes Per Day — SSD endurance metric indicating how many times the full drive capacity can be written per day
Bill of Materials — complete list of components and their costs required to manufacture the product
Underwriters Laboratories standard for software cybersecurity of network-connectable products
Self-Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Technology — drive health monitoring standard for SSDs and HDDs
Near Field Communication — short-range wireless technology for contactless data exchange at distances under 10 cm
Biometric Information Privacy Act — Illinois state law governing collection of biometric data including facial recognition
California Privacy Rights Act — California state law expanding consumer data privacy rights
National Institute of Standards and Technology Special Publication — guidelines for firmware resilience and update integrity
Artificial intelligence inference performed locally on the device rather than in the cloud
System-generated alarm when sensor communication loss or physical interference is detected

stakeholders.name: Residential Homeowner
stakeholders.concerns: Family safety, ease of use, reliability during power outages, false alarm minimization, privacy of recorded footage.
stakeholders.expectations: A security system that is always on, easy to control from a smartphone, and provides instant alerts when something unusual happens. Must work even when internet or power is down.
stakeholders.notes: Primary revenue source. Represented through customer surveys (CS-2025-041) and user stories (US-2025-022). Focus groups conducted quarterly.

stakeholders.name: SecureHome Insurance Group
stakeholders.concerns: Video evidence quality for claims processing, system uptime guarantees, tamper detection, data retention compliance.
stakeholders.expectations: High-resolution video surveillance with reliable storage that meets evidentiary standards. System must demonstrate continuous uptime for policy discount eligibility.
stakeholders.notes: Insurance partner requiring minimum 1080p video at 30fps for claim validation. Partnership agreement IP-2025-003 defines technical requirements.

stakeholders.name: National Safety Compliance Authority
stakeholders.concerns: UL 2900-1 cybersecurity compliance, data privacy regulations (GDPR, CCPA), electrical safety certification, battery disposal regulations.
stakeholders.expectations: Full compliance with applicable safety and cybersecurity standards. Documentation of conformity assessment. Annual audit readiness.
stakeholders.notes: Regulatory requirement REG-2025-008 mandates 72hr battery backup. Legal department (LD-2025-011) manages UL 2900-1 certification process.

stakeholders.name: AegisGuard Field Service Team
stakeholders.concerns: Ease of installation, diagnostic access, firmware update process, component replaceability, mean time to repair.
stakeholders.expectations: Modular hardware design allowing component-level replacement. Remote diagnostic capability to reduce truck rolls. Clear fault codes and service documentation.
stakeholders.notes: Service team handles installation, maintenance, and warranty repairs. Currently 45 technicians across 12 regions. Average 3.2 service calls per installation per year.

stakeholders.name: AegisGuard Product Development
stakeholders.concerns: Technical feasibility, development timeline, integration complexity, testing infrastructure, scalability of architecture.
stakeholders.expectations: Clear, testable requirements with defined acceptance criteria. Stable interfaces between subsystems. Adequate time for verification and validation activities.
stakeholders.contactInfo: Dr. Amir Rashid, Chief Engineer — a.rashid@aegisguard.example.com
stakeholders.notes: Engineering team of 18. Using agile methodology with 2-week sprints. Current development platform is ARM Cortex-M7 with FreeRTOS.

stakeholders.name: Municipal Emergency Services
stakeholders.concerns: False alarm rate, integration with central monitoring station, alarm verification protocol, response priority classification.
stakeholders.expectations: System must support CMS (Central Monitoring Station) integration via Contact ID protocol. False alarm rate below 2% to avoid fines and maintain response priority.
stakeholders.notes: Municipal ordinance requires verified alarm before dispatch. Systems with >5 false alarms per quarter are deprioritized. Contact ID protocol mandatory for monitored systems.

stakeholders.name: AegisGuard Executive Leadership
stakeholders.concerns: Market competitiveness, unit cost, time to market, brand reputation, return on investment, differentiation from competitors.
stakeholders.expectations: Product launch within 14 months. Bill of materials under $185 per unit. Feature parity or superiority versus Ring, SimpliSafe, and ADT offerings.
stakeholders.notes: Board-approved budget of $4.2M for AegisGuard Pro development. Monthly executive review on 3rd Wednesday. Go/no-go gate review at CDR milestone.

stakeholders.name: Data Privacy Officer
stakeholders.concerns: GDPR compliance, CCPA compliance, data minimization, consent management, right to erasure, cross-border data transfer restrictions.
stakeholders.expectations: All personal data processing must have documented legal basis. Video footage encrypted at rest and in transit. User consent flows for all data collection. Data retention policy enforced automatically.
stakeholders.notes: Legal department reference LD-2025-011. Privacy Impact Assessment required before launch. Annual GDPR audit scheduled for Q3.

interfaces.name: Sensor Hub to Control Panel Data Link
interfaces.dataItems: sensor_state (enum: OPEN/CLOSED/TAMPER), sensor_id (uint16), timestamp (uint64), battery_level (uint8), signal_strength (int8)
interfaces.physicalChar: 2.4 GHz ISM band, AES-128 encrypted, mesh topology, range 30m indoor
interfaces.notes: Primary sensor communication link. Uses Zigbee 3.0 for low-power mesh networking. Failover to 915 MHz ISM band if Zigbee hub unavailable. See ICD-2025-001.

interfaces.name: Control Panel to Cloud Backend
interfaces.physicalChar: Wi-Fi 802.11ac or Ethernet RJ-45, TLS 1.3 encrypted
interfaces.notes: MQTT broker hosted on AWS IoT Core. QoS Level 1 for alarm events, QoS Level 0 for telemetry. Automatic reconnection with exponential backoff.

interfaces.name: Notification Gateway to Mobile Push
interfaces.dataItems: device_token (string), notification_payload (JSON: title, body, priority, category), delivery_receipt (JSON)
interfaces.physicalChar: HTTPS, OAuth 2.0 bearer tokens, certificate-based auth for APNS
interfaces.notes: Dual-provider delivery for redundancy. If APNS fails, retry 3x at 5s intervals. FCM supports both Android and web push.

interfaces.name: Camera Module to Video Storage
interfaces.dataItems: h264_video_stream (1080p30), motion_metadata (JSON: region, confidence, timestamp), snapshot_jpeg (on-demand)
interfaces.physicalChar: PoE (802.3af), Cat6 cabling, RTSP streaming protocol
interfaces.notes: Video retention: 30 days local, 7 days cloud. Motion-triggered recording reduces storage by ~60%. ONVIF Profile S compliant.

interfaces.name: Control Panel to Keypad Display
interfaces.physicalChar: 4-wire bus (SDA, SCL, VCC, GND), max cable length 3m, pull-up resistors 4.7k ohm
interfaces.notes: Tamper detection via heartbeat polling every 500ms. If keypad disconnects, alarm triggers after 10s grace period. PIN never transmitted in cleartext.

interfaces.name: System to Central Monitoring Station
interfaces.dataItems: contact_id_event (SIA DC-05 format: account, event_code, zone, timestamp), heartbeat (supervision signal)
interfaces.physicalChar: TLS-encrypted IP connection, primary + backup receiver, SIA DC-07 compliant
interfaces.notes: Municipal requirement for professional monitoring. Contact ID protocol per SIA DC-05. Supervision signal every 60s.

useCases.title: Homeowner Arms System Remotely
useCases.trigger: Homeowner opens AegisGuard mobile app and selects arm mode
useCases.preconditions:
1. System is in Disarmed state
2. All entry sensors report CLOSED state
3. Homeowner has authenticated via mobile app
4. Network connectivity available (Wi-Fi or cellular)
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Homeowner opens the AegisGuard mobile application
2. System displays current system status (Disarmed) and sensor summary
3. Homeowner selects 'Arm Away' mode
4. System verifies all door/window sensors are in CLOSED state
5. System initiates 60-second exit delay countdown
6. System transitions to Armed Away mode
7. System sends push notification confirming arm status
8. System begins monitoring all sensor zones
useCases.alternativeFlows:
4a. Sensor not ready:
  4a.1 System displays list of open sensors with zone names
  4a.2 Homeowner can choose 'Force Arm' to bypass open zones
  4a.3 System logs bypassed zones and arms remaining sensors

5a. Network interruption during arm:
  5a.1 System queues arm command locally
  5a.2 System completes arm sequence using local processing
  5a.3 System syncs status to cloud when connectivity restores
useCases.postconditions:
1. System is in Armed Away mode
2. All non-bypassed sensors are actively monitored
3. Arm event logged with timestamp and method (remote)
4. Cloud status synchronized
useCases.notes: Most frequently used scenario per user analytics. Average 2.3 arm/disarm cycles per day per household. Exit delay configurable 30-120 seconds.

useCases.title: Intrusion Detected While Armed
useCases.trigger: Door or window sensor detects state change to OPEN while system is Armed
useCases.preconditions:
1. System is in Armed (Away or Stay) mode
2. Sensor is not bypassed
3. Sensor battery level above minimum threshold
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Sensor detects state change (CLOSED to OPEN) within 2 seconds
2. Sensor hub transmits alarm event to Control Panel via Zigbee
3. Control Panel validates sensor ID and zone assignment
4. Control Panel initiates entry delay (if entry zone) or immediate alarm
5. If entry delay expires without valid disarm: System triggers full alarm
6. System activates siren at 100+ dB
7. System sends push notification and SMS to homeowner within 5 seconds
8. System transmits Contact ID alarm to Central Monitoring Station
9. System begins recording video from nearest camera
10. CMS operator receives alarm and initiates dispatch protocol
useCases.alternativeFlows:
4a. Entry zone with valid code:
  4a.1 Homeowner enters valid PIN within entry delay
  4a.2 System disarms and cancels alarm sequence

7a. Push notification fails:
  7a.1 System retries via SMS
  7a.2 System retries push via alternate provider

8a. CMS communication failure:
  8a.1 System retries on backup communication path
  8a.2 System logs communication failure for review
useCases.postconditions:
1. Alarm event logged with full sensor data and timestamps
2. Homeowner notified via at least one channel
3. CMS notified (if monitored)
4. Video evidence captured and stored
5. System remains in Alarm state until manually cleared
useCases.notes: Critical path scenario. Response time SLA: sensor trigger to notification < 7 seconds total. False alarm rate target: < 2% per quarter.

useCases.title: Installer Configures New System
useCases.trigger: New AegisGuard Pro unit delivered and ready for customer installation
useCases.preconditions:
1. Hardware components unpacked and physically mounted
2. Technician has installer credentials
3. Customer Wi-Fi network available
4. All sensors positioned at designated locations
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Technician connects Control Panel to power and network
2. Technician logs into installer configuration mode via keypad
3. System enters Setup Wizard mode
4. Technician configures Wi-Fi credentials
5. System connects to cloud and registers device
6. Technician initiates sensor enrollment mode
7. For each sensor: trigger sensor, system auto-detects and assigns zone
8. Technician names each zone (e.g. 'Front Door', 'Kitchen Window')
9. Technician configures notification preferences with homeowner
10. Technician runs system self-test (all sensors, siren, notifications)
11. System generates installation report
12. Technician exits installer mode and hands off to homeowner
useCases.alternativeFlows:
4a. Wi-Fi connection fails:
  4a.1 Technician verifies credentials and retries
  4a.2 If persistent: configure Ethernet backup connection

7a. Sensor not detected:
  7a.1 System displays troubleshooting guide
  7a.2 Technician checks battery and range
  7a.3 Technician can manually add sensor by serial number

10a. Self-test fails:
  10a.1 System identifies failing component
  10a.2 Technician replaces or repositions component
  10a.3 Repeat self-test for affected zones
useCases.postconditions:
1. All sensors enrolled and zones named
2. Cloud connectivity established
3. Self-test passed for all components
4. Installation report generated and saved
5. System in Disarmed ready state
useCases.notes: Average installation time: 2.5 hours for 8-sensor system. Installer app available on tablet for guided setup. Installation report auto-uploaded to service management system.

useCases.title: Homeowner Reviews Camera Footage
useCases.trigger: Homeowner receives motion alert or wants to review recorded footage
useCases.preconditions:
1. At least one camera is online and recording
2. Homeowner has authenticated via mobile app
3. Video storage (local or cloud) is accessible
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Homeowner opens app and navigates to Camera view
2. System displays live feeds from all active cameras
3. Homeowner selects a camera for full-screen view
4. Homeowner taps Timeline to access recorded footage
5. System displays motion-event markers on timeline
6. Homeowner scrubs to desired timestamp
7. System streams recorded video at selected time
8. Homeowner can save clip or share with authorities
useCases.alternativeFlows:
2a. Camera offline:
  2a.1 System shows last known status and offline duration
  2a.2 System offers to send diagnostic ping to camera

6a. Footage not available (beyond retention):
  6a.1 System displays retention policy notice
  6a.2 System suggests cloud storage upgrade if applicable
useCases.postconditions:
1. Homeowner has viewed requested footage
2. Any saved clips stored in user's clip library
3. View event logged for audit trail
useCases.notes: Video playback must support 1x, 2x, 4x speed. Clip export formats: MP4 (H.264). Maximum clip length: 10 minutes per export.

useCases.title: System Operates on Battery Backup
useCases.trigger: AC power loss detected by Control Panel
useCases.preconditions:
1. System is powered and operational
2. Battery backup is charged above 20%
3. System is in any operational mode
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Control Panel detects AC power loss within 100ms
2. System seamlessly transitions to battery backup
3. System sends power failure notification to homeowner
4. System reduces non-essential functions (dims keypad, reduces polling)
5. System maintains all security monitoring functions
6. System reports battery level every 30 minutes to homeowner
7. At 15% battery: System sends low battery critical alert
8. At 5% battery: System sends imminent shutdown warning
9. System performs graceful shutdown preserving all logs
useCases.alternativeFlows:
2a. Battery failed or below minimum:
  2a.1 System sends emergency shutdown notification
  2a.2 System logs final state and shuts down

6a. Power restored during battery operation:
  6a.1 System transitions back to AC power
  6a.2 System sends power restored notification
  6a.3 System resumes full functionality
  6a.4 Battery begins recharging
useCases.postconditions:
1. Security monitoring maintained for up to 72 hours
2. All events during battery operation logged
3. Homeowner notified of power status changes
4. Graceful shutdown if battery depleted
useCases.notes: Battery backup requirement: 72 hours minimum per regulatory requirement REG-2025-008. Power consumption in degraded mode: ~2W vs ~8W normal operation.

useCases.title: Technician Performs Remote Diagnostics
useCases.trigger: Customer reports issue or system self-reports fault condition
useCases.preconditions:
1. System has cloud connectivity
2. Technician has service credentials
3. Service ticket created in management system
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Technician logs into service portal
2. Technician locates customer system by account ID
3. System displays real-time health dashboard
4. Technician reviews sensor status, signal strengths, battery levels
5. Technician checks event log for anomalies
6. Technician initiates remote diagnostic test
7. System runs component-level diagnostics and reports results
8. Technician identifies root cause and determines resolution
9. If remote fix possible: Technician pushes configuration update
10. Technician updates service ticket with findings
useCases.alternativeFlows:
3a. System offline:
  3a.1 Portal shows last known state and offline timestamp
  3a.2 Technician schedules on-site visit

7a. Diagnostic test fails:
  7a.1 System reports specific failure codes
  7a.2 Technician consults troubleshooting knowledge base
  7a.3 If hardware fault: schedule replacement visit
useCases.postconditions:
1. Root cause identified and documented
2. Resolution applied or on-site visit scheduled
3. Service ticket updated with diagnostic data
4. Customer notified of outcome
useCases.notes: Remote resolution rate target: 40% of service calls. Average remote diagnostic session: 15 minutes. Reduces truck rolls by estimated 35%.
